concept: Mechanically-induced conformational changes in cortical crosslinking proteins like α-actinin may propagate asymmetric force generation through hierarchical actomyosin networks, potentially amplifying local mechanosensitive switches into cell-scale polarized deformations. Optogenetic activation of specific crosslinker domains combined with super-resolution imaging could reveal how conformational cascades drive symmetry-breaking in cortical contractility patterns.

rationale.statement: Cortical actomyosin networks exhibit asymmetric contractility patterns essential for polarized cellular shape changes during morphogenesis. These networks contain mechanosensitive crosslinking proteins like α-actinin that undergo force-dependent conformational changes, altering their binding properties and enabling local mechanical perturbations to propagate through hierarchical cytoskeletal architectures into larger-scale asymmetric deformations.

Nonlinear feedback mechanisms in actomyosin networks, including F-actin buckling under compression, break force symmetry and amplify local perturbations into directed contractile flows. Collective conformational switching of multiple α-actinin molecules can alter bulk network mechanical properties, demonstrating how molecular-scale changes translate to cellular-scale contractility patterns through biophysically validated mechanisms.

Near-infrared optogenetic systems using upconversion nanoparticles enable precise, localized protein activation without tissue attenuation or cellular stress. Pulsed activation protocols with controlled kinetics align with millisecond-to-second conformational dynamics observed in mechanosensitive proteins, while single-molecule studies confirm that piconewton-scale forces can trigger α-actinin conformational changes under physiological conditions.

Super-resolution microscopy with optimized frame rates captures both rapid conformational changes and slower network reorganizations in living cells. Multi-frame statistical techniques achieve high spatial resolution with low excitation power, enabling direct visual correlation between optogenetically-induced molecular changes and subsequent cytoskeletal reorganization on the same biological sample.

This integrated optogenetic-imaging approach offers unique spatiotemporal resolution that significantly advances mechanobiology studies beyond traditional biochemical assays. The methodology enables causal linking of local molecular triggers to network-level mechanical responses, providing novel insights into hierarchical force integration mechanisms in non-muscle cells with implications for understanding pathological processes.
